title: Regulating the sex work industry would be ‘terrifying’, says lawyer Kathryn Adams | dailytelegraph.com.au
text:
OPINION: In March 2015, the Hornsby City Council in Sydney lost a landmark legal battle against a massage parlour after it was alleged that the parlour was operating as an illegal brothel.
The court held that, despite having evidence that sexual services were provided to a “sex spy” hired by the Council, the action failed as the Court was unable to prove that “enough sex” was being sold on the premises.
Despite the result of the legal battle resting on a technicality, Premier Mike Baird took a sledgehammer approach to the issue by announcing he would establish a Select Committee to review the current extent and nature of the brothel industry in New South Wales.
He has asked for the Committee to reflect on how effective regulation has been in the other states and territories of Australia.
Furthermore, Premier Baird has promised to look at the options for reform, including a scheme for registration or licensing of authorised brothels.
The response from the sex industry and other various human rights organisation has been resoundingly clear — reform of the New South Wales sex industry is not wanted, and doing so would set a dangerous precedent for the industry going forward.
The laws relating to sex work throughout Australia vary significantly. In South Australia, sex work is criminalised. That is, it is a criminal offence to provide sexual services in any way, shape or form.
In states such as Queensland and Victoria, a model exists where sex workers and establishments are licensed and are required to abide by strict regulation regarding the conduct of business.
In New South Wales, influenced by the recommendations of the Wood Royal Commission, the industry has enjoyed the decriminalisation of sex work since 1996, a model which was only just endorsed by Amnesty International last month as the best way to preserve the human rights of those who are involved in the industry.
As a result of decriminalisation, New South Wales’ sex industry is considered to be one of the most advanced sex industries in the world. It is accepted by leading human rights organisations that decriminalisation in New South Wales has lead to decreased physical and sexual violence, decreased rates of arbitrary arrest and detention, better HIV testing and medical interventions and removal of restrictions on healthcare, housing and other social and legal benefits.
It is argued by those in support of licensing of the sex industry that new barriers, including police checks and payment of exorbitant fees, should be introduced for the entire industry.
Among those in support of such a scheme is the New South Wales Police Deputy Commissioner, Nick Kaldas.
He told the inquiry yesterday that “there are clearly issues in the industry, in terms of servitude, the use of illegal workers and extortion by or involvement of organised crime and outlaw motorcycle gang groups”.
Accordingly, he was of the view that in response, the Select Committee should consider a recommendation that there should be a register of sex premises, including a list of sex workers as well as owners and managers, that the police can have access to.
Firstly, the New South Wales Police and the Australian Federal Police have always had the ability to deal with issues such as servitude, illegal workers and extortion. Adding a new layer of licensing is not a logical choice in the stemming of such crimes, but rather a duplication of enforcement action which can already be taken through use of police powers with respect to criminal activity.
The expense of shifting a new licensing scheme and bureaucracy would also be a significant burden on the tax payer. Furthermore, similar licensing models in Victoria and Queensland have been a comprehensive failure.
There is a high level of noncompliance, with 50 per cent of Victorian sex workers still operating illegally as of 2012. In Queensland, only 24 brothels have ever been licensed in the 14 years that regulation has been in place.
Of greater concern is the impact on the safety and welfare of sex workers.
Not only are they exposed to councils who use the practice of obtaining evidence through private investigators deceiving them into providing sexual services, the idea of placing themselves on government-maintained, permanent “sex worker registers” is terrifying.
It interferes with the privacy of the sex worker, limits the sex worker’s ability to travel and affects the access that the sex worker has to services. Many sex workers, when approached about whether they would voluntarily place their names on a list like this, were horrified with the idea of having to do so.
Non-compliance would be incredibly high. As such an entire population of workers would become ‘criminals’ overnight, simply for wanting to maintain a level of anonymity.
The message from various organisations, such as the Kirby Institute, UNSW, Touching Base, the AIDS Council, Family Planning, and Scarlet Alliance, the Australian Sex Workers Association, has been loud and clear.
The introduction of a licensing system would not only create a complex and ineffective bureaucracy, but it would place public health — and workers themselves — at risk.
As it has been stated by many leading academics in the area, “if it’s not broken, don’t fix it.”
Kathryn Adams is a lawyer specialising in human rights and sex work issues, as well as an advocate for the global decriminalisation of sex work. Follow her on Tiwtter @KateOnTheGo . The Sex Business 15:42 Play video
